sections.heading: Real-world Development experience
sections.lead: In addition to my education at NSCC, I was able to secure a co-operative work experience with Freewheeling Adventures where I completed two development projects for their database. Applying my technical knowledge to real-world business needs proved to be one of the best learning experiences I've had to date.

sections.heading: Where do I want to be?
sections.lead:
I have an entrepreneurial orientation, and want to put this to use in my career as a developer.
I will continue to work on my own projects, and want to be a part of an organization that promotes individuality, where I can share in the success and mourn their failures.

sections.heading: A Motivated and Project-Oriented Employee
sections.lead:
I have always followed my passion, and making development my career is no different.
My motivation to solve problems and understand systems has led me through studies in math and music, and is culminating in my career as a programmer.

sections.heading: Well Grounded in C++ Practices
sections.lead: While studying C++, I was exposed to industry best-practices and protocols. Given interesting mental-challenges, I was able to produce applications which display my knowledge of data structures, code-efficiency and my ability to creatively solve problems

sections.heading: Example: Predator Prey Simulation
sections.lead: My Humans vs. Zombies, predator prey simulation, is an excellent example of the techniques I have learned while developing in C++. This application displays my knowledge of operator overloading, polymorphism and code efficiency.

sections.heading: Knowledge From the Ground Up
sections.lead:
During my time at NSCC, I have had a breadth of exposure to the versatility of PHP.
Learning the fundamentals of the language, and how to utilize the extended PHP functionality, was a perfect lead-in to learning the Laravel framework.

sections.heading: Example: Custom Social Media Site
sections.lead: The best example of my experience in PHP is a Custom Social Media Site I made for sharing videos. Using laravel, I built a webpage with both a backend and frontend, using middleware to control access. I was also able to live-update the feed with short-polling.

sections.heading: Scaled for Enterprise
sections.lead: Java was the language where I first learned Object Oriented programming, and from there learned to program for enterprise edition. I have had experience developing numerous applications and am confident I can deliver business requirements with this increasingly powerful language.

sections.heading: Example: E-Commerce Web Application
sections.lead: Using EE4J and Primefaces within a Maven project, I delivered a fully functioning E-Commerce Web Application which utilizes JDBC to access a MySQL database, and simultaneously makes rest calls to a Jersey Backend.

sections.heading: Advanced OOP and Windows Development
sections.lead: C# was a major focus of my studies at NSCC, where I used the .NET framework to learn concepts like multi-threading, and dependency injection with IOC containers.

sections.heading: Example: UWP Application
sections.lead: One of my final projects was a UWP Application which utilizes the Media Wiki API to search and browse wikipedia pages.

sections.heading: Foundation and Inspiration
sections.lead: Python was the first programming language I learned. It was my initial exposure to programmatic logic, and was the inspiration for me to pursue development as a career. Since that time I have begun working through Project Euler and started learning machine learning via Lynda.com and Coursera.

sections.heading: Example: Three-Part Chord Calculator
sections.lead: In December of 2016, I developed a Three-Part Chord calculator to help with my music practice. Using PyQt5, and Python 3, I developed a GUI to display and output every three-part chord, in all inversions and positions in every key, major and minor.

sections.heading: Example: MNIST Handwritten Digit Recognition
sections.lead: Using the MNIST Database of Handwritten Digits, and the eBook by Michael Neilsen, Neural Networks and Deep Learning, I was part of a project to use a Neural Network which can recognize handwritten digits.

sections.heading: Web Styling
sections.lead: Having had familiarity with CSS for a number of years it has been a revelation to be introduced to Sass. The ability to finally treat styling as another programmatic language makes working with CSS as exciting as the other languages I have come to love.

sections.heading: Example: Sass-styled Page
sections.lead: Working through the Lynda.com tutorial by Ray Villalobos, I was able to trans-pile a simple CSS file using Sass methodology and mixins.

sections.heading: Data Driven Application Developer
sections.lead: During the summer of 2017, I was able to secure a co-operative education position with a local business, Freewheeling Adventures, where I was able to put my learning to use as a Database Developer.

sections.heading: Example: Data-Normalization Project
sections.lead: During my time with Freewheeling I was able to complete two major projects. One of which was a database normalization and migration for their Inn Management system. I was able to build new tools to utilize the data, and save hours of work by producing valuable reports and embedded protocols with the new database structure.

sections.heading: Not Only SQL
sections.lead: After having learned the essentials of Relational Database systems, wrapping my head around the principles of NoSQL was initially a mind-warp. But after grasping the 'in-memory' aspect, I have come to recognize the power and potential of NoSQL Databases

sections.heading: Example: Node.js Backend With MongoDB
sections.lead: Using the concept of a simple content sharing site, I worked on a project to create a RESTful API using Node.js and MongoDB

sections.heading: Vanilla, jQuery, and beyond
sections.lead: Following a structured path, I learned vanilla JavaScript first, followed by jQuery, and am now applying that knowledge towards learning frameworks like React, Vue, and Angular.

sections.heading: Example: Vanilla Maze-Game
sections.lead: Using my knowledge of Vanilla JavaScript, I built a maze-game entirely in JS, which you can try for yourself.

sections.heading: Example: React Framework
sections.lead: This entire portfolio has been written in react, initially pulling the data you are reading now from a JSON file, however I have an additonal example in the form of a front-end content sharing site, which makes calls to a Node.js backend.
